data.title: Veteran trio eager to land NHL contracts at Flames camp
data.meta_description: Ladislav Smid, if he tugged on a yellow don’t-hit-me smock, could be plopped into the middle of practices right now. But no. Because that, according to Calgary Flam…
data.text:
Ladislav Smid, if he tugged on a yellow don’t-hit-me smock, could be plopped into the middle of practices right now. But no. Because that, according to Calgary Flames coach Bob Hartley, would not be practical for the defender — who is not cleared for contact — or for anyone else on the ice.

Article content

Ladislav Smid, if he tugged on a yellow don’t-hit-me smock, could be plopped into the middle of practices right now.

But no.

We apologize, but this video has failed to load.

Try refreshing your browser, or

tap here to see other videos from our team.

Veteran trio eager to land NHL contracts at Flames camp Back to video

Because that, according to Calgary Flames coach Bob Hartley, would not be practical for the defender — who is not cleared for contact — or for anyone else on the ice.

He explained.

“We’re telling the world that we’re the hardest-working team and we want our guys intense,” Hartley said Friday afternoon as Smid skated with the similarly drydocked Paul Byron at WinSport. “I’m not going to put him in a situation where he might get hit. And I’m not going to put a kid who’s really ready to make a push for our team — (who) wants to hit everything that moves — in that situation.

Article content

“Suddenly, he’s faced with Smiddy? If he hits him and gets in trouble — or doesn’t hit him and still gets in trouble — it’s a no-win situation.”

Hartley plans to grant Smid permission next week to join the group sessions. Which is only the start.

Uncertainty surrounding the veteran rearguard, who is recovering from neck surgery, surely cracks opens the door for three grizzled gents here on professional tryout offers.

Douglas Murray, Aaron Johnson, and Ryan Wilson would all embrace the seventh-defenceman role. (The top six spots are spoken for.)

However, they were unfazed by Smid’s absence.

“The way this league works, numbers don’t really matter,” said Murray, 35. “When you first started playing as a young guy, you looked at numbers — ‘This guy has played so-many seasons. And this guy has scored so-many goals last year.’ This business is all about winning. (So) if you show enough where you can help the team put up wins, it doesn’t matter who’s here right now — or not.

“Obviously, if it was five one-way contracts (instead of seven), would my odds be better? Of course. You just come in and try to perform your best — the rest is out of your control. Once you start trying to think about what the GM or the coach thinks, you’re in trouble.”

Article content

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

Johnson’s take was no different.

“I’m not looking too far ahead,” said the 32-year-old. “It’s just a matter of playing well and preparing for the season — wherever that is.

“We all kind of hang out, the three of us (defencemen on tryouts), at the hotel. We’re all in the same pot, same situation.”

Johnson, a member of the Flames before being traded to the Edmonton Oilers, with a third-round pick, for Steve Staios in March 2010, isn’t overwhelmed by his standing.

A no-guarantee audition? Better than nothing.

“The way my career’s gone, I think I’ve been in this situation for 12 years,” said Johnson, grinning. “You don’t really think too much about the PTO. You think of it almost like you have a contract. Just play the same way and focus.”

This fall, more veterans than ever are attending camps without deals.

“(Teams) don’t want to give away those last contracts — the 48th, 49th, 50th (NHL) contracts,” said Johnson. “They want to be able to make moves.”

Not that he — or Murray or Wilson — is shying away.

“As a hockey player, you love that challenge,” said Johnson. “You’re in an opportunity where you really have to show everything you’ve got — that’s kind of way I look at it. Go out and enjoy it and show that you can still play.”

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

The past two winters, Johnson has turned in full campaigns in the American Hockey League — 2013-14 in Hartford, 2014-15 in Binghamton. In 2012-13, he got into 10 games with the Boston Bruins — his most recent taste of the NHL.

Johnson would happily take a two-way pact.

Murray, however, wants to stick in the NHL.

“That’s the only way you’ve got to think about it,” said Murray, who skated in the 2014 playoffs with the Montreal Canadiens. “I go into every season thinking I’m going to win the Stanley Cup — it doesn’t matter what team you’re on.

“Once you start reaching shorter than the stars, you’ll be in trouble. My goal is to get an NHL contract. If that doesn’t happen and something else (like a two-way deal) shows up, that’s a conversation for then.”

For the Bromma, Sweden, native, this is the last chance.

Something he acknowledged, admitting that, ill-advisedly, he had taken his status as an NHLer for granted.

“The game was changing and I didn’t change myself as far as weight and speed and all that,” said Murray, a veteran of more than 500 games. “Now we’ll find out if it’s too little too late.”

In his prime, the 6-foot-3 bruiser played at 248 pounds.

Now he’s 18 pounds lighter.

“When I was 17 or 18,” said Murray, with a chuckle, “that’s the last time I weighed 230.”
